Description.val: The Air Force's FY 2014 President's Budget retains the MC-12W LPA mission in the Active Duty.  All investment funding will remain in the Active Duty PE 0305230F, ISR for Irregular Warfare, through the FYDP.  Funding for this exhibit contained in PE 0305230F.

Justification.val: Where applicable, justification for individual modifications is provided in the P-3A exhibits.

Description.val:
Liberty Project Aircraft (LPA), military designation MC-12W, is the Air Force's multi-role, medium altitude, manned aircraft system performing an intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance (ISR) mission coupled with a target acquisition (TA) capability. LPA was initiated through the SECDEF-directed ISR Task Force to address the ever-increasing Combatant Commander's requirements to satisfy ISR capabilities shortfalls in on-going Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO).  Program management is the responsibility of the 645th Aeronautical Systems Group (AESG, BIG SAFARI System Program Office) and L-3 Communications (L-3Com) is on contract as the prime integrator for the MC-12W LPA system.

FY 2014 funds will be used to continue system updates in response to user needs and requirements to include, but not be limited to, airframe components, SIGINT sensors systems, data links, Electro-Optical/Infrared (EO/IR) sensors, and the mission management system as prioritized by Air Combat Command's Requirements Working Group.

The composition of the MC-12W LPA fleet of 42 aircraft as First Quarter FY 2013 is as follows:
- Four (4) King Air 350 aircraft remain in the MC-12W LPA Baseline 1 configuration and are on loan indefinitely to USSOCOM
- Two (2) King Air 350 aircraft have been retrofitted from their MC-12W LPA Baseline 1 configuration to the MC-12W LPA Baseline 3 configuration
- The seventh and last King Air 350 aircraft is currently being retrofitted from its MC-12W LPA Baseline 1 configuration to the MC-12W LPA Baseline 3 configuration
- Five (5) King Air 350ER aircraft procured with the FY 2010 OCO funding were delivered in the MC-12W Baseline 3 configuration
- Thirty (30) King Air 350ER aircraft were delivered in the original MC-12W  Baseline 2 configuration.  All these aircraft will be retrofitted from the Baseline 2  to the Baseline 3 configuration through FY 2016, predicated on operational needs and availability of re-deployed MC-12W LPA Baseline 2 aircraft.

Milestone/Development Status

645 AESG selected L-3 Communications (L-3Com), Greenville, TX as their prime contractor for the integration and modification of Hawker Beechcraft Corporation (HBC) King Air 350/350ER aircraft into MC-12W Liberty Project Aircraft (LPA) intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance (ISR) platforms.  L-3Com modified and delivered 37 MC-12W LPA to the Air Force between 27 April 2009 and 18 August 2010.  L-3Com was awarded a subsequent contract on 21 December 2010 to modify five additional King Air 350ER aircraft to the MC-12W LPA Baseline 2 configuration (LPA #38 through #42).  This contract was amended in August 2011 to include the integration of the enhanced High Definition (HD) capabilities to the EO/IR sensor ball, an intercom system and Tactical Air Navigation (TACAN) unit installation to what is now referred to as the Baseline 3 configuration.  L-3Com delivered all five of the MC-12W LPA (#38 through #42) purchased with FY 2010 OCO in the First Quarter of FY 2012.  The MC-12W LPA fleet build of 42 aircraft is complete. 

All currently planned or anticipated updates are based upon commercially available (commercial off-the-shelf or COTS) or proven military systems (government off-the-shelf or GOTS) that do not require additional development to install or integrate on the MC-12W LPA. 

Twenty-seven MC-12W LPA are currently deployed to the USCENTCOM theater of operations to support Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO).  Six MC-12W LPA are currently utilized as dedicated training assets operated by the 9th Reconnaissance Wing (ACC), Beale AFB, CA.  Four Baseline 1 MC-12W LPA configured aircraft were put on loan to USSOCOM in December 2011 for an indefinite period of time to augment their C-12 JavaMan program.  The five remaining MC-12W LPA are currently in some aspect of modification by L-3Com. 

L-3Com is on contract to modify and/or retrofit the entire MC-12W LPA fleet, minus the four aircraft on loan to USSOCOM, to the MC-12W Baseline 3 configuration.  This effort was initiated in FY 2011 and projected to continue through FY 2016.
